xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:title: CIS Google Chrome Benchmark

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This document provides prescriptive guidance for establishing a secure configuration posture for Google Chrome Browser. This guide was tested against Google Chrome v68.0.3440.75. To obtain the latest version of this guide, please visit http://benchmarks.cisecurity.org. If you have questions, comments, or have identified ways to improve this guide, please write us at feedback@cisecurity.org.

xccdf:Benchmark.xccdf:notice: BACKGROUND. The Center for Internet Security ("CIS") provides benchmarks, scoring tools, software, data, information, suggestions, ideas, and other services and materials from the CIS website or elsewhere ("Products") as a public service to Internet users worldwide. Recommendations contained in the Products ("Recommendations") result from a consensus-building process that involves many security experts and are generally generic in nature. The Recommendations are intended to provide helpful information to organizations attempting to evaluate or improve the security of their networks, systems, and devices. Proper use of the Recommendations requires careful analysis and adaptation to specific user requirements. The Recommendations are not in any way intended to be a "quick fix" for anyone's information security needs. NO REPRESENTATIONS, WARRANTIES, OR COVENANTS. CIS makes no representations, warranties, or covenants whatsoever as to (i) the positive or negative effect of the Products or the Recommendations on the operation or the security of any particular network, computer system, network device, software, hardware, or any component of any of the foregoing or (ii) the accuracy, reliability, timeliness, or completeness of the Products or the Recommendations. CIS is providing the Products and the Recommendations "as is" and "as available" without representations, warranties, or covenants of any kind. USER AGREEMENTS. By using the Products and/or the Recommendations, I and/or my organization ("We") agree and acknowledge that: 1. No network, system, device, hardware, software, or component can be made fully secure; 2. We are using the Products and the Recommendations solely at our own risk; 3. We are not compensating CIS to assume any liabilities associated with our use of the Products or the Recommendations, even risks that result from CIS's negligence or failure to perform; 4. We have the sole responsibility to evaluate the risks and benefits of the Products and Recommendations to us and to adapt the Products and the Recommendations to our particular circumstances and requirements; 5. Neither CIS, nor any CIS Party (defined below) has any responsibility to make any corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; or to notify us of the need for any such corrections, updates, upgrades, or bug fixes; and 6. Neither CIS nor any CIS Party has or will have any liability to us whatsoever (whether based in contract, tort, strict liability or otherwise) for any direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, or special damages (including without limitation loss of profits, loss of sales, loss of or damage to reputation,loss of customers, loss of software, data, information or emails, loss of privacy, loss of use of any computer or other equipment, business interruption, wasted management or other staff resources or claims of any kind against us from third parties) arising out of or in any way Connected with our use of or our inability to use any of the Products or Recommendations (even if CIS has been advised of the possibility of such damages), including without limitation any liability associated with infringement of intellectual property, defects, bugs, errors, omissions, viruses, worms, backdoors, Trojan horses or other harmful items. GRANT OF LIMITED RIGHTS. CIS hereby grants each user the following rights, but only so long as the user complies with all of the terms of these Agreed Terms of Use: 1. Except to the extent that we may have received additional authorization pursuant to a written agreement with CIS, each user may download, install and use each of the Products on a single computer; 2. Each user may print one or more copies of any Product or any component of a Product that is in a .txt, .pdf, .doc, .mcw, or .rtf format, provided that all such copies are printed in full and are kept intact, including without limitation the text of this Agreed Terms of Use in its entirety. RETENTION OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS; LIMITATIONS ON DISTRIBUTION. The Products are protected by copyright and other intellectual property laws and by international treaties. We acknowledge and agree that we are not acquiring title to any intellectual property rights in the Products and that full title and all ownership rights to the Products will remain the exclusive property of CIS or CIS Parties. CIS reserves all rights not expressly granted to users in the preceding section entitled "Grant of limited rights." Subject to the paragraph entitled "Special Rules" (which includes a waiver, granted to some classes of CIS Members, of certain limitations in this paragraph), and except as we may have otherwise agreed in a written agreement with CIS, we agree that we will not (i) decompile, disassemble, reverse engineer, or otherwise attempt to derive the source code for any software Product that is not already in the form of source code; (ii) distribute, redistribute, encumber, sell, rent, lease, lend, sublicense, or otherwise transfer or exploit rights to any Product or any component of a Product; (iii) post any Product or any component of a Product on any website, bulletin board, ftp server, newsgroup, or other similar mechanism or device, without regard to whether such mechanism or device is internal or external, (iv) remove or alter trademark, logo, copyright or other proprietary notices, legends, symbols or labels in any Product or any component of a Product; (v) remove these Agreed Terms of Use from, or alter these Agreed Terms of Use as they appear in, any Product or any component of a Product; (vi) use any Product or any component of a Product with any derivative works based directly on a Product or any component of a Product; (vii) use any Product or any component of a Product with other products or applications that are directly and specifically dependent on such Product or any component for any part of their functionality, or (viii) represent or claim a particular level of compliance with a CIS Benchmark, scoring tool or other Product. We will not facilitate or otherwise aid other individuals or entities in any of the activities listed in this paragraph. We hereby agree to indemnify, defend, and hold CIS and all of its officers, directors, members, contributors, employees, authors, developers, agents, affiliates, licensors, information and service providers, software suppliers, hardware suppliers, and all other persons who aided CIS in the creation, development, or maintenance of the Products or Recommendations ("CIS Parties") harmless from and against any and all liability, losses, costs, and expenses (including attorneys' fees and court costs) incurred by CIS or any CIS Party in connection with any claim arising out of any violation by us of the preceding paragraph, including without limitation CIS's right, at our expense, to assume the exclusive defense and control of any matter subject to this indemnification, and in such case, we agree to cooperate with CIS in its defense of such claim. We further agree that all CIS Parties are third-party beneficiaries of our undertakings in these Agreed Terms of Use. SPECIAL RULES. CIS has created and will from time to time create, special rules for its members and for other persons and organizations with which CIS has a written contractual relationship. Those special rules will override and supersede these Agreed Terms of Use with respect to the users who are covered by the special rules. CIS hereby grants each CIS Security Consulting or Software Vendor Member and each CIS Organizational User Member, but only so long as such Member remains in good standing with CIS and complies with all of the terms of these Agreed Terms of Use, the right to distribute the Products and Recommendations within such Member's own organization, whether by manual or electronic means. Each such Member acknowledges and agrees that the foregoing grant is subject to the terms of such Member's membership arrangement with CIS and may, therefore, be modified or terminated by CIS at any time. CHOICE OF LAW; JURISDICTION; VENUE. We acknowledge and agree that these Agreed Terms of Use will be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Maryland, that any action at law or in equity arising out of or relating to these Agreed Terms of Use shall be filed only in the courts located in the State of Maryland, that we hereby consent and submit to the personal jurisdiction of such courts for the purposes of litigating any such action. If any of these Agreed Terms of Use shall be determined to be unlawful, void, or for any reason unenforceable, then such terms shall be deemed severable and shall not affect the validity and enforceability of any remaining provisions. BY USING THE PRODUCTS I(WE) ACKNOWLEDGE THAT WE HAVE READ THESE AGREED TERMS OF USE IN THEIR ENTIRETY, UNDERSTAND THEM, AND I(WE) AGREE TO BE BOUND BY THEM IN ALL RESPECTS.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Items in this profile intend to:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: provide a clear security benefit; and
not inhibit the utility of the technology beyond acceptable means.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This profile extends the "Level 1" profile. Items in this profile exhibit one or more of the following characteristics:

xhtml:ul.xhtml:li: are intended for environments or use cases where security is paramount.
acts as defense in depth measure.
may negatively inhibit the utility or performance of the technology.

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostDomainList' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '.+'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Configure the required domain names for remote access hosts' is set to 'Enabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostDomainList' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '.+'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostRequireCurtain' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable curtaining of remote access hosts' is set to 'Enabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostRequireCurtain' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostFirewallTraversal' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable firewall traversal from remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostFirewallTraversal' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowClientPairing' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable PIN-less authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'RemoteAccessHostAllowClientPairing' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DefaultCookiesSetting' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '4'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L2) Ensure 'Default cookies setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Keep cookies for the duration of the session)" -> "Ensure 'DefaultCookiesSetting' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '4'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'DefaultPluginsSetting' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '3'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Default Flash Setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Click to Play)" -> "Ensure 'DefaultPluginsSetting' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '3'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure '1' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '*'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Configure extension installation blacklist' is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all extensions)" -> "Ensure '1' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '*'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure '1' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '*'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure `Configure native messaging blacklist` is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all messaging applications)" -> "Ensure '1' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '*'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'PasswordManagerEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable saving passwords to the password manager' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'PasswordManagerEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AuthSchemes' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to 'ntlm, negotiate'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Supported authentication schemes' is set to 'Enabled' (ntlm, negotiate)" -> "Ensure 'AuthSchemes' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to 'ntlm, negotiate'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AllowFileSelectionDialogs' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L2) Ensure 'Allow invocation of file selection dialogs' is set to 'Enabled'" -> "Ensure 'AllowFileSelectionDialogs' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AllowOutdatedPlugins' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Allow running plugins that are outdated' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'AllowOutdatedPlugins' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'BlockThirdPartyCookies' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Block third party cookies' is set to 'Enabled'" -> "Ensure 'BlockThirdPartyCookies' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'BackgroundModeEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'BackgroundModeEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'AutoFillEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'AutoFillEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CloudPrintProxyEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'CloudPrintProxyEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'MetricsReportingEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'MetricsReportingEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'SitePerProcess' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable Site Isolation for every site' is set to 'Enabled'" -> "Ensure 'SitePerProcess' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '1'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'CloudPrintSubmitEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'CloudPrintSubmitEnabled' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:Value.xccdf:title: Ensure 'ImportSavedPasswords' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'
xccdf:Value.xccdf:description: This variable is used in Rule "(L1) Ensure 'Import saved passwords from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'" -> "Ensure 'ImportSavedPasswords' is 'Windows: Registry Value' to '0'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: The following structure of this guide mirrors how it is structured in the Google Chrome Group Policy template.
This section contains recommendations for Google Chrome.
This section contains recommendations for Configuring Remote Access Options

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure the required domain names for remote access hosts' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the user to configure a required host domain that is imposed on remote access hosts. When enabled, hosts can only be shared using accounts that are registered to the specified domain.

xhtml:blockquote.xhtml:p: This policy is deprecated. Please use RemoteAccessHostDomainList instead.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is disabled or not set, then hosts can be shared using any account.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled and enter domain.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Configure the required domain names for remote access hosts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, hosts can be shared only using accounts registered on the specified domain name.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable curtaining of remote access hosts' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows the user to disable a remote user's physical input and output while the remote connection is in progress.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is disabled or not set, then both local and remote users can interact with the host when it is being shared.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable curtaining of remote access hosts
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, host's physical input and output devices are disabled while a remote connection is in progress.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable firewall traversal from remote access host' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables the usage of STUN servers which allows remote clients to discover and connect to a machine even if they are separated by a firewall. By disabling this feature, in conjunction with filtering outgoing UDP connections, the machine will only allow connections from machines within the local network.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, remote clients can discover and connect to this machines even if they are separated by a firewall.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable firewall traversal from remote access host
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled and outgoing UDP connections are filtered by the firewall, this machine will only allow connections from client machines within the local network.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable or disable PIN-less authentication for remote access hosts' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables a user to opt-out of using user-specified PIN authentication and instead pair clients and hosts during connection time.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled or not configured, users can opt to pair clients and hosts at connection time, eliminating the need to enter a PIN every time.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to ``Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Configure remote access options\Enable or disable PIN-less authentication
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users will be required to enter PIN every time.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains recommendations for Content Settings

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Default cookies setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Keep cookies for the duration of the session)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to set whether websites are allowed to set local data. Setting local data can be either allowed for all websites or denied for all websites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this policy is left not set, 'AllowCookies' will be used and the user will be able to change it.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default cookies setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, cookies will be cleared when the session closes.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Default Flash Setting' is set to 'Enabled' (Click to Play)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to set whether websites are allowed to automatically run plugins. Automatically running plugins can be either allowed for all websites or denied for all websites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Malicious plugins can cause browser instability and erratic behavior so setting the value to click to play will allow a user to only run necessary plugins.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled with click to play selected from the drop down.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Content Settings\Default Flash Setting
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is enabled, users must click plugins to allow their execution

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section contains recommendations for Extensions

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Configure extension installation blacklist' is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all extensions)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Enabling this setting allows you to specify which extensions the users can NOT install. Extensions already installed will be removed if blacklisted.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: This can be used to block extensions that could potentially allow remote control of the system through the browser. If there are extensions needed for securing the browser or for enterprise use these can be enabled by configuring the extension whitelist.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Extensions\Configure Extension Installation Blacklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Any installed extension will be removed unless it is specified on the extension whitelist.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section contains settings for Native Messaging.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure `Configure native messaging blacklist` is set to 'Enabled' ("*" for all messaging applications)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows you to specify which native messaging hosts that should not be loaded.
NOTE: A blacklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blacklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the whitelist.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: For consistency with Plugin and Extension policies, native messaging should be blacklisted by default, requiring explicit administrative approval of applications for whitelisting. Examples of applications that use native messaging is the 1Password password manager.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Native Messaging\Configure native messaging blacklist
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
A blacklist value of '*' means all native messaging hosts are blacklisted unless they are explicitly listed in the whitelist.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section contains recommendations for Password Manager

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable saving passwords to the password manager' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome will memorize passwords and automatically provide them when a user logs into a site. By disabling this feature the user will be prompted to enter their password each time they visit a website.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, users can have Google Chrome memorize passwords and provide them automatically the next time they log in to a site. An intruder who has unrestricted access to your computer for even a minute can view and copy all of your saved passwords just by visiting an easy-to-remember settings page: chrome://settings/passwords.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Password manager\Enable the password manager
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this settings is disabled, users cannot save new passwords but they may still use passwords that have been saved previously.

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section contains Policies for HTTP Authentication.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Supported authentication schemes' is set to 'Enabled' (ntlm, negotiate)

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Specifies which HTTP authentication schemes are supported by Google Chrome.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Possible values are 'basic', 'digest', 'ntlm' and 'negotiate'. Basic and Digest authentication do not provide sufficient security and can lead to submission of users password in plaintext or minimal protection.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled:(ntlm, negotiate).
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Policies for HTTP Authentication\Supported authentication schemes

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.
This section is intentionally blank and exists to ensure the structure of the Google Chrome benchmark is consistent in future releases.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L2) Ensure 'Allow invocation of file selection dialogs' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Allows access to local files on the machine by allowing Google Chrome to display file selection dialogs.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Preventing users from uploading documents can help limit the loss of sensitive information.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow invocation of file selection dialogs
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If you enable this setting, users can open file selection dialogs as normal.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Allow running plugins that are outdated' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome enables the use of outdated plugins. By disabling this feature Chrome will not prompt the user to use an outdated plugin.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Running the most up-to-date version of a plugin can reduce the possibility of running a plugin that contains an exploit or security hole.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Allow running plugins that are outdated
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If you disable this setting, outdated plugins will not be used and users will not be asked for permission to run them.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Block third party cookies' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows cookies to be set by web page elements that are not from the domain in the user's address bar. Enabling this feature prevents third party cookies from being set.
NOTE: Third Party Cookies and Tracking Protection are required for many business critical websites, including SalesForce and Office365.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Blocking third party cookies can help protect a user's privacy by eliminating a number of website tracking cookies.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Block third party cookies
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
Enabling this setting prevents cookies from being set by web page elements that are not from the domain that is in the browser's address bar.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows for processes started while the browser is open to remain running once the browser has been closed. It also allows for background apps and the current browsing session to remain active after the browser has been closed. Disabling this feature will stop all processes and background applications when the browser window is closed.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If this setting is enabled, vulnerable or malicious plugins, apps and processes can continue running even after Chrome has closed.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Continue running background apps when Google Chrome is closed
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this policy is set to Disabled, background mode is disabled and cannot be controlled by the user in the browser settings.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable AutoFill' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: Chrome allows users to auto-complete web forms with saved information such as address, phone number and credit card numbers. Disabling this feature will prompt a user to enter all information manually.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: If an attacker gains access to a user's machine where the user has stored auto save data, information could be harvested or used to gain access to more systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable AutoFill
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, AutoFill will be inaccessible to users.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google Chrome to act as a proxy between Google Cloud Print and legacy printers connected to the machine.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this option will prevent users from printing possible confidential enterprise documents through the cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Google Cloud Print Proxy
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users cannot enable the proxy, and the machine will not be allowed to share its local printers with Google Cloud Print.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This Setting controls anonymous reporting of usage and crash-related data about Google Chrome to Google.
NOTE: This policy is not available on Windows instances that are not joined to a Microsoft® Active Directory® domain.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Anonymous crash/usage data can be used to identify people, companies and information, which can be considered data ex-filtration from company systems.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable reporting of usage and crash-related data
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, this information is not sent to Google.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable Site Isolation for every site' is set to 'Enabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This policy controls is every website will load into its own process.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Chrome will load each website in its own process. So, even if a site bypasses the same-origin policy, the extra security will help stop the site from stealing your data from another website.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Enabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable Site Isolation for every site
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If the policy is enabled, each site will run in its own process which will cause the system to use more memory.

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting enables Google Chrome to submit documents to Google Cloud Print for printing.
NOTE: This only affects Google Cloud Print support in Google Chrome. It does not prevent users from submitting print jobs on web sites.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: Disabling this option will prevent users from printing possible confidential enterprise documents through the cloud.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Enable submission of documents to Google Cloud print
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, users cannot print to Google Cloud Print from the Chrome print dialog

xccdf:Rule.xccdf:title: (L1) Ensure 'Import saved passwords from default browser on first run' is set to 'Disabled'

xccdf:description.xhtml:p: This setting controls if saved passwords from the default browser can be imported.

xccdf:rationale.xhtml:p: In Chrome, passwords can be stored in plain-text and revealed by clicking the “show” button next to the password field by going to chrome://settings/passwords/.

xhtml:p.xhtml:p: To establish the recommended configuration via Group Policy, set the following UI path to Disabled.
xhtml:p.xhtml:code: Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\Google\Google Chrome\Import saved passwords from default browser on first run
xhtml:p.xhtml:p: Impact:
If this setting is disabled, saved passwords from other browsers are not imported.
